Award.AwardTitle: Hurricane Maria Relief Funding for Restoration of Scientific Capabilities at the Arecibo Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal describes the repair of critical infrastructure at Arecibo Observatory (AO) damaged by Hurricane Maria in September 2017. The repairs conducted in this supplement include the most urgent: site backup power (including repairing and rewinding three out of the four site generators and installation of a solar backup array), building repairs, inspections of critical infrastructure, and preparations for more complicated repairs (e.g. engineering studies for the replacement of the line feed that was completely destroyed during Hurricane Maria). The proposal outlines the planned activities in detail, all of which are in support of returning the site to a world-class working science observatory. Observations obtained by AO contribute to the fulfillment of scientific goals set out by the astronomy, planetary science, ionospheric physics, and the space weather communities. The radar system at AO is a unique asset, but currently cannot be used due to the needed generator repairs. Until these repairs are conducted, radar-imaging of near-earth asteroids, for example, is not possible. The observation and categorization of near-earth objects (NEOs) is a Congressional mandate. AO is one of the leading education and public outreach centers worldwide, and a top attraction for students in Puerto Rico.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project goal is to restore, repair and modify the Arecibo Observatory infrastructure and equipment to ensure the safety, continuity of the research operations and educational programs. This initial $2M funding award was used to complete critical repairs to infrastructure impacted by Hurricane Maria, and to purchase equipment and materials that increased the facility?s resiliency for the 2018 hurricane season. Note that an additional 12.3M were granted on a separate award to perform all necessary actions to restore full scientific capability at the site. All planned restoration activities under his award were completed successfully and include the following:

  • Rewinding of 3 generators and Purchase of generator spare parts
  • Repairs to visiting scientist quarters, HF facility roof, and exterior building infrastructure
  • Removal of 403MHz line feed debris and replacement of damaged primary reflector panels
  • Repairs to HF Heliox lines
  • Repair to interior building structure and assets, including HVAC units.
  • Site landscape safety inspection, Debris removal, and Replacement of Landscaping equipment
  • Inspection, cleaning and repair of tie down blocks and rim wall footings
  • Inspection and repair of site power infrastructure
  • Water pump procurement and replacement
  • Motor vehicle replacements
  • Communication equipment upgrades

 

In addition to these important repair and resiliency tasks, other tasks were performed under this award at the request of the National Science Foundation to mitigate risks in the subsequent 12.3M award and include:structural analysis for the replacement of the damaged primary suspension cable and preliminary requirements gathering for systems and equipment requiring restoration.

Additional task included emergency management training for key personnel, and development of robust emergency management Standard Operating Procedures (SOP).
